learning_outcomes.description: Apply the theoretical process engineering principles of unit operations in various food manufacturing processes

Use the engineering principles in various food engineering processes: crystallisation, rice processing, emulsification, spray drying, extrusion and water activity prediction in addressing scenarios in food process engineering
Undertake experiments related to food process engineering to determine both qualitative and quantitative outcomes
Apply food process engineering principles and techniques in collaborative practical sessions and individually analyse and report experimental outcomes.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment will examine students on their theoretical knowledge from lectures and tutorials in weeks 1 to 5.  

Scheduled outside of weekly lecture timeslot.  

Students will be provided a formula reference sheet for the exam.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This is an in-person exam with a fixed schedule.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Prac presentation on each of the following topics: Water activity, Extrusion, and Homogenization

A brief group practical presentation (SINGLE student) for each project is to be prepared in an online format and submitted by the due date.

The presentation should set for 20 minutes in length. Longer presentations will not have penalty.

Marking criteria:

Clarity of Communication (15%)

Demonstrates clear and confident explanation of key concepts. Shows strong understanding of both practical sessions and theoretical background. Language is appropriate, engaging, and avoids reading directly from a script. Uses examples or analogies where useful to enhance understanding.

Presentation Structure and Flow (15%)

Presentation follows a logical structure with a clear introduction, main body, and conclusion. Transitions between sections are smooth, and the overall flow supports audience comprehension.

Quality and Relevance of Visuals (15%)

Visuals are clear, well-formatted, and directly support the spoken content. Graphs and figures have properly labeled axes, units, and legends. Visuals include relevant equations or illustrations where needed, avoid unnecessary clutter, and limit the number of words.

Accuracy and Explanation of Calculations (20%)

Calculations and equations are used appropriately, applied correctly, and clearly explained. Shows understanding of what the numbers mean, their relevance to theory, and how they relate to practical observations. Assumptions and limitations are clearly acknowledged.

Connection to Lecture Topics (20%)

Presentation demonstrates a strong link to key course concepts and lecture material. Uses correct terminology and references core models or frameworks introduced in the course. Shows how the presentation content fits within the broader learning objectives.

Timing and Length Management (5%)

The presentation stays within the allotted time. Pacing is even, content is covered efficiently, and the speaker maintains control of timing without rushing or finishing too early.

Use and Selection of References (10%)

At least four credible and relevant scientific references are used appropriately to support content. References are clearly cited and integrated into the discussion to justify methods, results, or interpretations.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) tools, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI or MT will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged appropriately.

Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students must submit Assessment task, in Blackboard, via the Turnitin link by the submission deadline. An electronic copy of every piece of assessment submitted should be retained.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
End of Semester Exam Period

8/11/2025 - 22/11/2025

Exam on lectures/tutorials (weeks 6 to 12)
assessments.task_description:
The final exam will consist mainly of questions related to food processing operations covered in lectures and tutorials from weeks 6 to 12, and will directly test understanding or food engineering principles and the ability to relate fundamental theory to practical situations encountered in industry.

Students will be provided a formula reference sheet for the exam.  

The exam will be an on-campus exam. Have your UQ student ID card available for your exam.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Delivered lectures covering a range of core food engineering topics, including water activity, sorption property prediction, crystallisation, size reduction, homogenisation and emulsification, particle engineering, spray drying, powder property analysis, rice processing, encapsulation techniques, extrusion, packaging technologies, and alternative processing methods


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures Delivered lectures covering a range of core food engineering topics, including water activity, sorption property prediction, crystallisation, size reduction, homogenisation and emulsification, particle engineering, spray drying, powder property analysis, rice processing, encapsulation techniques, extrusion, packaging technologies, and alternative processing methods

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials

Facilitated tutorials involving group-based problem-solving exercises on key food engineering topics, including water activity, sorption isotherms, crystallisation mechanisms, size reduction principles, homogenisation and emulsification dynamics, particle design, spray drying operations, powder characterisation, rice milling, encapsulation strategies, extrusion processes, packaging systems, and alternative processing techniques.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorials Facilitated tutorials involving group-based problem-solving exercises on key food engineering topics, including water activity, sorption isotherms, crystallisation mechanisms, size reduction principles, homogenisation and emulsification dynamics, particle design, spray drying operations, powder characterisation, rice milling, encapsulation strategies, extrusion processes, packaging systems, and alternative processing techniques.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Practicals

Led hands-on practical sessions involving group-based experiments on key food processing techniques, including measurement and analysis of water activity and sorption properties, homogenisation of food emulsions, characterisation of powder properties, spray drying of model formulations, and rice milling and quality assessment. The extrusion process was demonstrated to illustrate principles and equipment operation.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Practicals Led hands-on practical sessions involving group-based experiments on key food processing techniques, including measurement and analysis of water activity and sorption properties, homogenisation of food emulsions, characterisation of powder properties, spray drying of model formulations, and rice milling and quality assessment. The extrusion process was demonstrated to illustrate principles and equipment operation.
